cards.back:
f(x) ≈ f(x₀) + f'(x₀)(x - x₀)

This is the equation of the tangent line at x₀.
Also called first-order Taylor approximation.

f(x) ≈ f(x₀) + J|_{x₀} · (x - x₀)

where J is the Jacobian matrix.
Generalizes tangent line to tangent plane/hyperplane.

J[i,j] = ∂fᵢ/∂xⱼ

Matrix of all first partial derivatives.
Size: (# outputs) × (# inputs)

The point (x₀) around which you linearize.

In circuits: DC bias point / quiescent point.
Different operating points → different linear models!

r_d = V_T / I_Q

where V_T ≈ 26mV at room temperature
I_Q = DC bias current

Rule of thumb: r_d ≈ 26Ω at 1mA

Eigenvalues of Jacobian at equilibrium:

• All negative real parts → STABLE
• Any positive real part → UNSTABLE  
• Zero real part → MARGINAL (inconclusive)

1. Far from operating point (tangent diverges)
2. At bifurcation points (eigenvalues cross zero)
3. Discontinuous functions (no derivative)

Rule of thumb: Valid for ~10-20% deviation

Analysis of small AC signals around a DC operating point.

Process:
1. Find DC operating point
2. Linearize around it
3. Analyze AC with linear model

Used for amplifier gain, impedance, etc.

Linearization IS first-order Taylor series!

Linearization: f ≈ f₀ + f'(x-x₀)  [1st order only]
Taylor: f = f₀ + f'(x-x₀) + f''(x-x₀)²/2 + ... [all orders]

Linearization = simplest useful approximation

cards.front: Why do linear systems have superposition?
cards.back:
For linear L:
L(αx + βy) = αL(x) + βL(y)

Inputs add → outputs add.
Nonlinear systems: NO superposition!

This is why we linearize: to use superposition.

Nonlinear: dx/dt = f(x, u)

Linearized around (x₀, u₀):
Δẋ = A·Δx + B·Δu

where A = ∂f/∂x|₀, B = ∂f/∂u|₀

To solve f(x) = 0:

x_{n+1} = x_n - f(x_n)/f'(x_n)

This uses the tangent line to predict where f crosses zero.
Repeated linearization → converges to root.
